COLUMBIA, Mo. (AP) ‚Äî Former Missouri Gov. Eric Greitens, now a leading Republican Senate candidate, was physically abusive and demonstrated such ‚Äúunstable and coercive behavior‚Äù that steps were taken to limit his access to firearms, according to new allegations from his ex-wife revealed in court records on Monday.

The sworn affidavit from Sheena Greitens is part of an ongoing child custody dispute in Missouri. A public affairs professor at the University of Texas, she sought divorce from Eric Greitens after a sex scandal which led to his resignation as governor in June 2018. She‚Äôs now asking the court to move the custody case to Austin in part to spare her children from renewed public attention as Eric Greitens tries to mount a political comeback.

group.description:
This group embraces the traditionalism of those pioneers of the 1940s, 1950s, and 1960s known as the New Conservatives. The New Conservatives were a loose group of conservative academics and scholars who after the crisis of World War II revived interest in Western civilization and American cultural renewal. The New Conservatives also brought about a renaissance in the study of the life and work of Anglo-Irish statesman and philosopher Edmund Burke. Their immediate forebears included the New Humanists, the Distributists, T. S. Eliot, Ralph Adams Cram, C. S. Lewis, Herbert Agar, Bernard Iddings Bell, Christopher Dawson, and the Southern Agrarians.
Articles:
"Understanding Traditionalist Conservatism" by Mark C. Henrie
http://www.newpantagruel.com/

Radonna Butler (@butler_radonna) / Twitter

Alabama Republican Mo Brooks is calling for Mitch McConnell to be ousted as Senate GOP leader, making him the party‚Äôs third major Senate candidate to come out in favor of booting the Kentucky Republican.

‚ÄúAmerica can‚Äôt afford a Senate leader who is a weak-kneed, debt junkie, open-border RINO Republican and who, worse yet, sells out America for special interest group cash,‚Äù Brooks says in a new 90-second web advertisement.

Brooks joins two other Republican candidates ‚Äî Eric Greitens of Missouri and Kelly Tshibaka of Alaska ‚Äî in pushing for McConnell‚Äôs removal. All three are running staunchly anti-establishment campaigns and are aligning themselves with former President Donald Trump, who has repeatedly laced into McConnell over the past year.

_source.content: People have started to think saying "no" is a bad thing. Is it really? From Joshua Slocum @JoshuaSlocum and the Disaffected Podcast https://open.spotify.com/episode/4EMvuQ84HNLWTLw03dp5vV?si=Hv9e_7TsRhyFryp3G1LjFQ I wrote a free locals post last week about having adult-adult conversations versus parent-child conversations: https://hackingyourlife.locals.com/post/1859178/whenever-we-are-conversing-with-others-were-coming-from-a-standpoint-of-our-inner-child-adult-self The idea comes from Games People Play by Eric Berne, MD. I highly recommend reading that post to get a quick background on this. His book is also very good but somewhat difficult reading. In addition to that I wrote about how we need to defend our boundaries in this blog post: Should You ‚ÄúTake The Beating‚Äù Or Defend Your Boundaries? https://asabovebelowloa.com/should-you-take-the-beating-or-defend-your-boundariesTelling a child "no" is so important because it helps them to know what boundaries are. It helps them to recognize that they can't just do whatever they want to. People realize you have to tell your child "no" to touching a hot stove because it can hurt them, but they don't realize you have to tell your child "no" if they think they were born in the wrong body. That belief can hurt them too! If you don't raise a child with boundaries they grow up to be spoiled brats and authoritarian adults. As Joshua says, people have actually gotten to the point where they think it's bad to say "no" and they are actively hurting their children because of it. #parents #spoiled #gamespeopleplay #boundaries #justsayno
_source.contentraw:
People have started to think saying "no" is a bad thing. Is it really?

From Joshua Slocum @JoshuaSlocum and the Disaffected Podcast

https://open.spotify.com/episode/4EMvuQ84HNLWTLw03dp5vV?si=Hv9e_7TsRhyFryp3G1LjFQ

I wrote a free locals post last week about having adult-adult conversations versus parent-child conversations: https://hackingyourlife.locals.com/post/1859178/whenever-we-are-conversing-with-others-were-coming-from-a-standpoint-of-our-inner-child-adult-self

The idea comes from Games People Play by Eric Berne, MD. I highly recommend reading that post to get a quick background on this. His book is also very good but somewhat difficult reading.

In addition to that I wrote about how we need to defend our boundaries in this blog post: Should You ‚ÄúTake The Beating‚Äù Or Defend Your Boundaries? https://asabovebelowloa.com/should-you-take-the-beating-or-defend-your-boundaries

Telling a child "no" is so important because it helps them to know what boundaries are. It helps them to recognize that they can't just do whatever they want to. People realize you have to tell your child "no" to touching a hot stove because it can hurt them, but they don't realize you have to tell your child "no" if they think they were born in the wrong body. That belief can hurt them too!

If you don't raise a child with boundaries they grow up to be spoiled brats and authoritarian adults.

As Joshua says, people have actually gotten to the point where they think it's bad to say "no" and they are actively hurting their children because of it.

#parents #spoiled #gamespeopleplay #boundaries #justsayno

Eric Holcomb has signed legislation that requires all counties using certain voting machines to leave a paper trail before the 2024 presidential election.The new state law, HEA 1116, requires Indiana counties that use electronic voting machines to install ‚Äúvoter-verifiable paper audit trails‚Äù‚Äîa backup system that allows people to check their votes on a paper printout before confirming their votes, before the 2024 election.It also ‚Äúprovides that, after July 1, 2022, a county must meet certain requirements when using any direct record electronic voting system that does not include a voter-verifiable paper audit trail for an election,‚Äù according to the legislation.The measure also ‚Äúspecifies requirements of a statement that must be printed on the envelope of an absentee ballot application‚Äù and stipulates that voters will now have to provide a driver‚Äôs license number, state identification number, or the last four digits of their Social Security number when they submit an electronic request for an absentee ballot.It will also require counties to have an electronic poll book that has the ‚Äúcapacity to transmit certain information that a voter cast a provisional ballot,‚Äù an outline of the measure reads. The new law also extends a cybersecurity contract between Indiana counties and the Indiana Secretary of State‚Äôs Office until 2028.Most of Indiana‚Äôs counties use machines made by MicroVote, Election Systems & Software, Hart InterCivic, and Unisyn, according to the Indiana government‚Äôs website. Barbara Tully, of Indiana Vote by Mail, said during a Senate Appropriations Committee hearing on Feb. 24 that 59 of Indiana‚Äôs 92 counties use MicroVote.Holcomb, a Republican, signed the measure on March 15, while Indiana Secretary of State Holli Sullivan later praised the move.‚ÄúIt also allows me and the Secretary of State‚Äôs office to better partner with our county election administrators to do post-election recounts, if needed, as well as post-election audits,‚Äù Sullivan, a Republican, said in a statement to local media outlets.Sullivan said she believes electronic voting machines with paper ballot backups are the ‚Äúperfect blend,‚Äù adding that it allows for ‚Äúquick results and the ability to do a recount that is very reliable and fast.‚ÄùThe state will now provide funding by July 1 to every county that needs paper backup systems.The new law will also allow the secretary of state to ‚Äúdetermine the number of elections that are subject to a post-election audit,‚Äù changing the term ‚Äúrisk-limiting audit‚Äù to ‚Äúpost-election audit,‚Äù and other measures, according to the outline of the legislation.
_source.contentraw:
Indiana Gov. Eric Holcomb has signed legislation that requires all counties using certain voting machines to leave a paper trail before the 2024 presidential election.

The new state law, HEA 1116, requires Indiana counties that use electronic voting machines to install ‚Äúvoter-verifiable paper audit trails‚Äù‚Äîa backup system that allows people to check their votes on a paper printout before confirming their votes, before the 2024 election.

It also ‚Äúprovides that, after July 1, 2022, a county must meet certain requirements when using any direct record electronic voting system that does not include a voter-verifiable paper audit trail for an election,‚Äù according to the legislation.

The measure also ‚Äúspecifies requirements of a statement that must be printed on the envelope of an absentee ballot application‚Äù and stipulates that voters will now have to provide a driver‚Äôs license number, state identification number, or the last four digits of their Social Security number when they submit an electronic request for an absentee ballot.

It will also require counties to have an electronic poll book that has the ‚Äúcapacity to transmit certain information that a voter cast a provisional ballot,‚Äù an outline of the measure reads. The new law also extends a cybersecurity contract between Indiana counties and the Indiana Secretary of State‚Äôs Office until 2028.

Most of Indiana‚Äôs counties use machines made by MicroVote, Election Systems & Software, Hart InterCivic, and Unisyn, according to the Indiana government‚Äôs website. Barbara Tully, of Indiana Vote by Mail, said during a Senate Appropriations Committee hearing on Feb. 24 that 59 of Indiana‚Äôs 92 counties use MicroVote.

Holcomb, a Republican, signed the measure on March 15, while Indiana Secretary of State Holli Sullivan later praised the move.

‚ÄúIt also allows me and the Secretary of State‚Äôs office to better partner with our county election administrators to do post-election recounts, if needed, as well as post-election audits,‚Äù Sullivan, a Republican, said in a statement to local media outlets.

Sullivan said she believes electronic voting machines with paper ballot backups are the ‚Äúperfect blend,‚Äù adding that it allows for ‚Äúquick results and the ability to do a recount that is very reliable and fast.‚Äù

The state will now provide funding by July 1 to every county that needs paper backup systems.

The new law will also allow the secretary of state to ‚Äúdetermine the number of elections that are subject to a post-election audit,‚Äù changing the term ‚Äúrisk-limiting audit‚Äù to ‚Äúpost-election audit,‚Äù and other measures, according to the outline of the legislation.

Indiana Governor Signs Bill Mandating Paper Backup for All Voting Machines
Indiana Gov. Eric Holcomb signed a bill that requires all counties using certain voting machines to leave a paper trail before the 2024 presidential election.
The new state law, HEA 1116, requires Indiana counties that use electronic voting machines to install ‚Äúvoter-verifiable paper audit trails,‚Äù or a backup system that allows people to check their votes on a paper printout before confirming their votes, before the 2024 election.
It also ‚Äúprovides that, after July 1, 2022, a county must meet certain requirements when using any direct record electronic voting system that does not include a voter-verifiable paper audit trail for an election,‚Äù according to the bill.
The measure also ‚Äúspecifies requirements of a statement that must be printed on the envelope of an absentee ballot application‚Äù and stipulates that voters will now have to provide a driver‚Äôs license number or state identification number, or the last four digits of their Social Security number when they submit an electronic request for an absentee ballot.
Meanwhile, it will require countries to have an electronic poll book that has the ‚Äúcapacity to transmit certain information that a voter cast a provisional ballot,‚Äù an outline of the measure said. The new law also extends a cybersecurity contract between Indiana counties and the Indiana Secretary of State‚Äôs Office until 2028.
Most of Indiana‚Äôs counties use machines made by MicroVote, Election Systems & Software, Hart InterCivic, and Unisyn, according to the Indiana government‚Äôs website. Barbara Tully, of Indiana Vote by Mail, said during a Senate Appropriations Committee hearing on Feb. 24 that 59 of Indiana‚Äôs 92 counties use MicroVote.
Holcomb, a Republican, signed the measure on March 15, while Indiana Secretary of State Holli Sullivan later praised the move.
‚ÄúIt also allows me and the Secretary of State‚Äôs office to better partner with our county election administrators to do post-election recounts, if needed, as well as post-election audits,‚Äù Sullivan, a Republican, said in a statement to local media outlets.
Sullivan added that she believes electronic voting machines with paper ballot backups are the ‚Äúperfect blend,‚Äù adding that it allows for ‚Äúquick results and the ability to do a recount that is very reliable and fast.‚Äù
The state will now provide funding for every county that needs paper backup systems by July 1 of this year.
The new law will also allow the secretary of state to ‚Äúdetermine the number of elections that are subject to a post-election audit,‚Äù changing the term ‚Äúrisk-limiting audit‚Äù to ‚Äúpost-election audit,‚Äù and other measures, according to the outline of the bill.

The 22nd of March, as in 3/22, or 322 is coming up. 322 is the number associated with Order 322, or Skull and Bones, the Elite Fraternity out of Yale University, the Freemasonic HQ for Northern America. In Europe, we write March 22nd as 22/3, as in 223, which is the reflection of 322, and thus consider equals in numerology.
It‚Äôs also the third month or the year ‚Äô22, as in 3/22, or 322. March 22, 2022 will be a triple whammy for the satanic order.

As for more relevance on tomorrow‚Äôs date, March 22, we have the following:

March 22, 2022 = 3/22/2022 = 3 + 22 + 20 + 22 = 67
Order 322 = 67

It‚Äôs also a date with the Freemasonic ‚Äò47‚Äô-numerology, as in the 47 degrees on the Freemasonic compass.

March 22, 2022 = 3/22/22 = 3 + 22 + 22 = 47
Authority = 47
Government = 47 (run by Freemasons, controlled by the Jesuits)
Ukraine = 47

Keep in mind that the Georgia Guidestones will turn 42-years-old on March 22.

Freemason = 42
War = 42
World War = 42
Jesuit = 42

So, what to expect for March 22?
Previously years, there have been a lot of fake shootings, terror attacks and catastrophes on these dates. For example, the staged King Sooper‚Äôs shooting last year and the biggest earthquake in 140 years in Croatia the year before that. It‚Äôs also a day for ritualistic killings, so expect some famous people to die on March 22. For example, last year Fox producer Eric Spinato and LA Lakers‚Äô Elgin Baylor died by the numbers. The logotype for Skull and Bones comes from an ‚Äòossuary‚Äô, a symbol of death and destruction.

Perhaps we will see some kind of development of the fake war tomorrow. Some new staged attack, or perhaps even some real destruction or shooting made by the Ukrainian military on their own population (as seen previously with a lot of crisis actors.)

And it will be the 81st day of the year, which fits in nicely with the anniversary of the Georgia Guidestones.

Depopulation Agenda = 81
Forced Vaccination = 81
The New World Order = 81

In other words, we might also see something that furthers the depopulation agenda, such as vaccinations, digital ID‚Äôs, and social credit score systems. Those things we know they are working hard on implementing slowly behind the scenes at the moment while people are distracted with the theatre of war. Just as they recently implemented digital ID‚Äôs and a social credit score system in Ukraine ‚Äì a country that is supposedly at war ‚Äì but that did not hinder them to implement new complex systems and mobile phone apps. I guess a war is no hindrance at all, but I digress. We all know that it is staged and fake.
